Name: Triclocarban
Description: Triclocarban is a member of the class of phenylureas that is urea substituted by a 4-chlorophenyl group and a 3,4-dichlorophenyl group at positions 1 and 3 respectively. It has a role as a disinfectant, an antiseptic drug, an antimicrobial agent, an environmental contaminant and a xenobiotic. It is a dichlorobenzene, a member of monochlorobenzenes and a member of phenylureas. It is functionally related to a 1,3-diphenylurea.

plant_concentrations.Value: Triclocarban was detected in algae from Pecan Creek, TX down stream of a waste water treatment plant at concentrations of 219 to 401 ppb; upstream of the plant the compound was not detected (detection limit 10 ppb). Samples were collected Sept 2-5, 2005(1).

sediment_soil_concentrations.References: (1) Kumar KS et al; Arch Environ Contam Toxicol 58: 275-85 (2010) (2) Long ER et al; Environ Toxicol Chem 32(8): 1701-1710 (2013)
sediment_soil_concentrations.Value: SEDIMENT: In rivers around Savannah, GA, triclocarban was detected in sediment from the Savannah, Ogeechee and Vernon River at concentrations of 16-42, 11-37 and 16-52 ng/g, respectively, samples were collected Oct 2008(1). Triclocarban was also detected in sediment from Wilshire Pond, located near the Wilshire water treatment plant in Savannah, GA at a concentration of 588 ng/g, sampled Oct 2007(1). Triclocarban was present in 35% of marine sediments samples from Puget Sound, WA, with a maximum concentration of 16.6 ng/g dry weight; sampling was conducted during April and June 2010 at 40 locations(2).

sediment_soil_concentrations.References: (1) Miller TR et al; Environ Sci Technol 42: 4570-6 (2008) (2) Blair BD et al; Chemosphere 93(9): 2116-2123 (2013)
sediment_soil_concentrations.Value: SEDIMENT: Triclorcarban concentrations in a sediment core sample from Chesapeake Bay, MD had an average concentration of 2.59 mg/kg at the depth of 0-34 cm and <0.001 mg/kg for 34-40 cm(1). Mean triclocarban sediment concentrations ranged from below the detection limit of 1.4 ng/g at 3.2 km south of outfall to 33 ng/g at 1.6 km east from the South Shore Reclamation Facility, Milwaukee, WI on Lake Michigan. Grab samples were collected on May 15, 2009 and April 9, 2010. The mean triclocarban outfall concentrations were 170 and 510 ng/g from South Shore and nearby Jones Island Water Reclamation Facility, respectfully(2).

sediment_soil_concentrations.References: (1) Miller TR et al; Environ Sci Technol 42: 4570-6 (2008)
sediment_soil_concentrations.Value: SEDIMENT: Triclocarban concentrations in a sediment core sample from Jamaica Bay, NY were reported, with corresponding approximate year of deposition(1).
